skill.name: gh-ticket
skill.description: Create or update comprehensive GitHub issues that capture ALL context, requirements, and implementation details. Use when creating or updating tickets, issues, feature requests, or bug reports. Ensures no context is lost between ticket creation and implementation - the moment you ask for a ticket, there's maximum context available that will be lost if not captured now.

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill consisting of a single SKILL.md file (721 lines). It provides templates and guidance for writing comprehensive GitHub issues. No executable code, no file system access, no network calls, no command execution, and no environment variable access. The skill only contains markdown documentation with best practices and examples.

content.user_title: Create comprehensive GitHub issues with full context
content.value_statement: Context is lost the moment you stop thinking about a problem. This skill captures maximum context at ticket creation time, including requirements, implementation details, file locations, and acceptance criteria. The result is tickets that developers can implement immediately without asking follow-up questions.
actual_capabilities: Capture context at the moment of discovery before details are forgotten
Structure tickets with requirements, edge cases, and acceptance criteria
Cite exact file paths and line numbers for implementation guidance
Generate Mermaid diagrams to visualize complex workflows
Update existing issues with new context found during investigation
Create standardized ticket formats with consistent sections
limitations: Does not execute git commands or create issues directly (provides templates for manual use)
Requires user to gather initial context before using the skill
Does not integrate with project management tools beyond GitHub
Skill is guidance-only and does not access repositories programmatically

prompt_templates.title: Bug report
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a GitHub issue for a bug. The error occurred when [describe action]. The error message was: [paste error]. Files involved: [list files]. Current behavior: [what happens]. Expected behavior: [what should happen].

prompt_templates.title: Feature request
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a GitHub issue for a feature request. Background: [why this is needed]. Current state: [what exists now]. Desired state: [what should exist]. List 5 specific functional requirements as checkboxes.

prompt_templates.title: Update issue
prompt_templates.prompt: Update GitHub issue #123 with new context discovered during investigation. Found additional requirements: [list]. Related files: [list]. Error traces: [paste].

prompt_templates.title: Comprehensive spec
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a comprehensive GitHub issue using the full template. Context: [what triggered this]. Files examined: [list]. Findings: [what was discovered]. Requirements: [detailed list]. Implementation notes: [file paths, line numbers, suggestions]. Acceptance criteria: [testable outcomes].

output_examples.input: Create a GitHub issue for the login crash that happens when users enter invalid emails. The error is 'Cannot read property of undefined' in auth.ts line 45. Current behavior shows a generic 500 error. Expected behavior is a validation message.
output: Fix crash when submitting invalid email format in login form
Users experience app crash when entering malformed email addresses. Error shown is generic 500 instead of helpful validation.
Invalid email input causes uncaught exception. Server returns 500, client shows generic error message.
Client-side validation shows error message before submission. Server returns 400 with clear validation error.
- [ ] Add email format validation on client before submit
- [ ] Display error: 'Please enter a valid email address'
- [ ] Return 400 with validation error code for invalid emails
- [ ] Log invalid attempt with timestamp and input (masked)
- [ ] Multiple invalid attempts: rate limit appropriately
```TypeError: Cannot read property 'email' of undefined at auth.ts:45```

best_practices: Capture context immediately when you discover an issue - details fade fast
Cite exact file paths and line numbers so developers do not need to search
Break requirements into individual checkboxes with specific, testable outcomes
anti_patterns: Writing vague requirements like 'fix the auth bug' instead of specific behaviors
Missing error messages or stack traces that help developers diagnose issues
Creating tickets without acceptance criteria, leaving done state undefined

faq.question: Does this skill create GitHub issues directly?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides templates and guidance for writing comprehensive issues. You then use gh CLI or GitHub web interface to create or update tickets.

faq.question: What makes a ticket comprehensive?
faq.answer: A comprehensive ticket includes background context, current vs desired state, specific requirements as checkboxes, edge cases, acceptance criteria, file locations, and error messages.

faq.question: Can I use this with private repositories?
faq.answer: Yes. The templates work for any GitHub repository. Ensure you have appropriate permissions to create or edit issues in the target repository.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-based skill with no code execution. It only generates text templates. No data is sent to external services.

faq.question: How is this different from GitHub issue templates?
faq.answer: GitHub issue templates are static forms. This skill provides dynamic guidance that adapts to your specific context and helps you write more complete tickets.

faq.question: Should I create a new ticket or update an existing one?
faq.answer: Create a new ticket for new work items. Update an existing ticket when expanding vague issues, adding new requirements discovered during investigation, or clarifying scope.
